In South Australia, police have been accused of charging their alleged victims instead, to stop their allegations being properly investigated.

title.children: The Zaporizhzhia power plant used water from the destroyed Ukrainian dam. What happens now?

title.children: Fish and chip prices to rise with ban on major form of fishing, a fisheries scientist says

image.altText: A lion cub and a black leopard cub hug each other while they sleep.

items.synopsis: The war in Ukraine has not only destroyed infrastructure and claimed human lives, but the natural environment and wildlife have been decimated and could take decades to recover when the war finally ends.

title.children: The full extent of Ukraine's environmental damage isn't known, but what has been discovered already worries experts

image.altText: A woman in green and a man in blue standing on a driveway, with trees in the background.

items.synopsis: It's been two years after a powerful storm brought down trees across the Dandenong Ranges, east of Melbourne, many are still struggling to repair and rebuild from that night, and not a single home has been rebuilt.

title.children: Ben thought his 'forever home' was well insured, but the cost of rebuilding is beyond his family's means

image.altText: Scott Boland smiles as teammates surround him

items.synopsis: Scott Boland was always going to do well in English conditions with a Duke ball, but it was still impressive to see him do it as Australia stayed in control of the ICC World Test Championship final against India at The Oval.

title.children: Five things we learnt at the WTC Final: Brilliant Boland backs up hype

image.altText: A blonde woman dribbling a soccer ball in the middle of a field

items.synopsis: Gippsland Times journalist Zoe Askew was suspended and fined $600 by the local league she plays in after publishing a report which criticised the behaviour of a match official.

title.children: Journalist's penalty for reporting on referee conduct 'a dangerous crossover between work and recreation'

image.altText: Australian currency is seen next to a wages graph

items.synopsis: CBA economists slash forecasts, put odds of a recession this year at 50:50. The ASX is on the rise. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: 50 per cent chance of a recession says CBA, ASX follows Wall St tech rally

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has finished the Friday session with a modest gain, with the ASX 200 closing 0.3 per cent higher, and the All Ordinaries index rising by a third of a per cent. Despite the day's solid finish, that leaves the ASX 200 0.3 per cent lower for the week — its third straight weekly fall — which isn't all that surprising given a pretty sharp decline on Tuesday after the RBA's rate rise. Here's how the sectors closed: Resources companies made up most of the top moving stocks, while it was a bit of a mixed bag for the biggest falls of the session: The ASX will be closed on Monday, due to the King's Birthday public holiday in some states, so this blog will be back on your screens from early Tuesday AM. But you can still catch The Business on Monday night for your finance fix — 8:45pm AEST on ABC News Channel and after the Late News on ABC TV. Next week will see Westpac's monthly consumer confidence index and the NAB business survey released on Tuesday, with the all-important employment figures due for release on Thursday, so a fair bit happening. In the meantime, enjoy your weekend, however many days it may be!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Positive end for ASX but still in the red for the week

children.content: The local share market has
finished the Friday session with a modest gain
, with
the ASX 200 closing 0.3 per cent higher
, and the All Ordinaries index rising by a third of a per cent.
Despite the day's solid finish, that leaves
the ASX 200 0.3 per cent lower for the week
— its third straight weekly fall — which isn't all that surprising given a pretty sharp decline on Tuesday after the RBA's rate rise.
Here's how the sectors closed:
ASX 200 sectors at the close
(Refinitiv)
Resources companies made up most of the top moving stocks, while it was a bit of a mixed bag for the biggest falls of the session:
Biggest % moves on ASX 200
(ASX)
The ASX will be closed on Monday, due to the King's Birthday public holiday in some states, so this blog will be back on your screens from early Tuesday AM.
But you can still catch
The Business
on Monday night for your finance fix — 8:45pm AEST on ABC News Channel and after the Late News on ABC TV.

Next week will see Westpac's monthly consumer confidence index and the NAB business survey released on Tuesday, with the all-important employment figures due for release on Thursday, so a fair bit happening.
In the meantime, enjoy your weekend, however many days it may be!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In some unwelcome-for-borrowers, welcome-for-savers, but altogether expected news, Commonwealth Bank and ANZ have both confirmed increases to their variable rate home loan rates. In line with the Reserve Bank's 0.25 of a percentage point increase to the cash rate on Tuesday, CBA and ANZ mortgages will have their rates increased by 0.25% from 16 June. There are also similar increases to the interest customers will receive on some savings accounts and term deposits. Earlier in the week, Westpac announced its variable home loan rates would also rise by 0.25%, effective 20 June, while offering a new term deposit.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA, ANZ increase mortgage rates

children.content: In some unwelcome-for-borrowers, welcome-for-savers, but altogether expected news,
Commonwealth Bank
and
ANZ
have both confirmed
increases to their variable rate home loan rates
In line with the Reserve Bank's 0.25 of a percentage point increase to the cash rate on Tuesday, CBA and ANZ mortgages will have their rates
increased by 0.25% from 16 June
There are also similar increases to the interest customers will receive on some savings accounts and term deposits.
Earlier in the week,
Westpac announced its variable home loan rates would also rise by 0.25%, effective 20 June
, while offering a new term deposit.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Embattled US cryptocurrency exchange Binance has suspended US dollar deposits and warned fiat currency withdrawals could be paused within a matter of days. In a tweet addressing its customers, Binance accused the US Securities and Exchange Commission of "using extremely aggressive and intimidating tactics" as part of a pursuit against crypto. The exchange said that "irrespective of the baseless claims" its payment and banking partners intend to pause its fiat currency channels as early as June 13, forcing it to transition into a crypto-only exchange — essentially, if customers want to cash out into US dollars anytime soon, they should get in quick. This week, the SEC sued both Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, and competitor Coinbase, escalating its crackdown on the industry. It has alleged a range of offences against Binance and its founder Changpeng Zhao, accusing him of operating a "web of deception". You can watch more on the crypto crackdown here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Crypto exchange Binance slams US regulators for 'intimidation'

US cryptocurrency exchange Binance
has suspended US dollar deposits and warned fiat currency withdrawals could be paused within a matter of days.
In a tweet addressing its customers,
Binance accused the US Securities and Exchange Commission of "using extremely aggressive and intimidating tactics"
as part of a pursuit against crypto.
The exchange said that "irrespective of the baseless claims" its payment and banking partners intend to pause its fiat currency channels as early as June 13, forcing it to
transition into a crypto-only exchange
— essentially, if customers want to cash out into US dollars anytime soon, they should get in quick.
This week,
the SEC sued both Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, and competitor Coinbase
, escalating its crackdown on the industry.
It has
alleged a range of offences against Binance and its founder Changpeng Zhao,
accusing him of operating a "web of deception".
You can watch more on the crypto crackdown here:

items.synopsis: The Barunga Festival gets underway, marking 35 years since Indigenous leaders presented the Barunga Statement to former prime minister Bob Hawke. So, what's changed since then?

title.children: It's 35 years since Bob Hawke was presented with the Barunga Statement. What's changed?

image.altText: A young girl sits in the centre of the jaws of a large shark with her sister in a wheelchair behind her

items.synopsis: The McWaters have two daughters with childhood dementia as a result of Batten Disease. They say they are luckier than some as they get to see their children grow up, but they want to see a better understanding of the disease and respite options.

title.children: Childhood dementia will cut these sisters' lives short. Their parents want better respite services — not sympathy
